metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of mixed forest station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the Sidaoqiao mixed forest station from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (101.134° E, 41.990° N) was located on a tamarix and populous forest (Tamarix chinensis Lour. and Populus euphratica Olivier.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 874 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (28 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (28 m, north), air pressure (in tamper box), rain gauge (28 m, south), four-component radiometer (24 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (24 m, south, vertically downward), two photosynthetically active radiation (24 m, south, one vertically upward and one vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m), and soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28 m; RH_28 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_28 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_28 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_up and PAR_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100, Ts_160, Ts_200, Ts_240 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100, Ms_160, Ms_200, Ms_240 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2019-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What are the primary components and processes involved in hydrometeorological data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: Hydrometeorological data collection in arid and semiarid regions involves observing radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These observations are typically conducted using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, and data collection also includes groundwater table data.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'oasis–desert interactions' refer to, and why is it significant in environmental research?
Definition.Answer: The term 'oasis–desert interactions' refers to the exchange processes of energy, water vapor, and carbon between oasis and desert ecosystems. Understanding these interactions is significant for recognizing the ecological balance, supporting sustainable development, and achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security in oasis-desert areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges in data collection for oasis-desert ecosystems compare to those faced in collecting meteorological data in mixed forest stations?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems faces challenges related to environmental degradation, such as drying rivers and desertification, whereas mixed forest stations deal with issues like ensuring consistent data collection despite canopy cover and varying microclimates. Both environments require robust data quality control to manage missing or erroneous data.

Interpretation.Question: How might the installation height and orientation of various sensors in a meteorological station influence the accuracy and reliability of data collected in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: In the described dataset, sensors such as air temperature, humidity, and wind speed and direction are mounted at a height of 28 meters and oriented towards the north. The installation height and orientation can affect data accuracy by minimizing disturbances from the ground or nearby structures and ensuring consistent exposure to environmental conditions. This setup aims to capture representative atmospheric conditions in the oasis-desert interface without interference from local topography or vegetation dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data quality control might arise from long-term observations of soil temperature and moisture at multiple depths, and how could these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data quality control for long-term soil temperature and moisture observations include sensor drift, data gaps, and noise from external factors like precipitation or temperature fluctuations. The dataset mentioned addresses these challenges by ensuring consistency in data collection frequency (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with specific values (-6999), and removing duplicates or out-of-range values. Regular calibration and maintenance of sensors, along with redundancy in sensor placement, could further improve data quality.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the direct measurement of turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon, providing insights into exchange processes at the land-atmosphere interface. This method captures high-temporal-resolution data that can reveal patterns and anomalies in ecosystem dynamics, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of how these exchanges influence the ecological stability and carbon balance in arid and semiarid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in maintaining data quality and consistency when collecting meteorological data in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological environment degradation challenges, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes and intensification of land desertification, which can impact data quality and consistency.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is long-term observation data crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for achieving a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for comprehensive data processing and quality control in hydrometeorological data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involve collecting diverse datasets, such as radiation, soil heat flux, and temperature profiles, which require careful handling to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the quality and reliability of datasets when implementing rigorous data processing and quality control measures in the context of oasis–desert ecosystem observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing rigorous data processing and quality control measures can enhance the quality and reliability of datasets by ensuring that data is free from errors such as missing values, duplicate records, and outliers. This approach can also help maintain consistent data formatting, which is critical for long-term observations necessary to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of long-term observational data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems affect our understanding of carbon balance in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including long-term observational data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems can significantly enhance our understanding of carbon balance in arid regions by providing insights into the role these areas play as carbon sinks. This information is crucial for recognizing the interactions between oasis and desert systems and their impact on the global carbon cycle.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of utilizing a suite of observational datasets from multiple sources, such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, on the accuracy of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange models in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a suite of observational datasets from multiple sources can increase the accuracy of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange models in oasis–desert ecosystems by offering a comprehensive understanding of various interacting factors. This approach allows for more precise modeling of complex ecological dynamics, supporting sustainable development and ecological stability in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems through data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why should observational datasets include both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in observational datasets helps to present a comprehensive view of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, which are critical for understanding these ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collected from automated weather stations in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve ensuring that there are 144 data points collected daily, with missing data marked as -6999, removing duplicate records, discarding data that exceed physical meaning or instrument range, and marking questionable data with red text. The data includes various meteorological parameters such as air temperature, relative humidity, air pressure, precipitation, wind speed, wind direction, radiation, and soil temperature, which are observed with sensors installed at specific heights and orientations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to integrate and archive long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methods involve data collection using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, along with automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data. This data is collected, processed, and archived, with parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles captured. These datasets are then made available through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing and quality control techniques enhance the reliability of observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing and quality control techniques enhance reliability by ensuring that each day contains 144 data points (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceed physical meaning or instrument ranges, and highlighting questionable data in red, which are critical for maintaining dataset integrity.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in maintaining accurate long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems, considering the ecological and climatic dynamics?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers, degraded vegetation, intensified desertification, and frequent dust storms, which complicate maintaining accurate long-term datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why might certain expected energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange patterns not be observable in oasis–desert ecosystems using current data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The interaction dynamics in oasis–desert systems are complex and require quantitative understanding through long-term observations, which may be hindered by environmental degradation and data collection limitations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the role of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in enhancing the data quality for flux measurements in oasis–desert regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers play a significant role in enhancing data quality for flux measurements by providing half-hourly turbulent flux data. This high temporal resolution is essential for capturing variations in energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are critical for understanding the dynamics of oasis–desert interactions and supporting sustainable development.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the main challenges in collecting accurate soil moisture and temperature profiles in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in collecting accurate soil moisture and temperature profiles in inland river basins include the potential for ecological environment degradation and the technical difficulties in maintaining consistent sensor accuracy over time. Addressing these challenges may involve regular calibration, employing robust data quality control procedures, and integrating supplementary datasets to validate and cross-check measurements.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data processing and quality control are performed to ensure the reliability of meteorological datasets in this type of environment.
Assertion.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure includes ensuring complete daily data entry, removing duplicates, deleting data outside physical or instrumental limits, marking questionable data, and maintaining consistent date and time formatting.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is significant for data collection in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Maintaining this balance is crucial for sustainable oasis development because it helps understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are vital for ecological security, carbon peaking, and carbon neutrality in these ecosystems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used for capturing meteorological and soil parameters in arid and semi-arid regions, detailing the types of sensors and measurement techniques employed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for capturing meteorological and soil parameters in arid and semi-arid regions involve the use of automatic weather stations that measure air temperature, relative humidity, air pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and soil moisture profiles. Sensors are mounted at various heights and depths to capture comprehensive environmental data. For example, air temperature and humidity sensors are installed at 28m, wind sensors at 28m, radiation sensors at 24m, and soil probes at various depths from 0cm to 240cm. These stations provide data at regular intervals, such as every 10 minutes, with quality control processes in place to ensure data accuracy and reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in maintaining long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems and how these challenges are addressed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges faced in maintaining long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, land desertification, and dust storms. These challenges are addressed by establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations that provide continuous data acquisition and monitoring. Quality control measures, such as data validation and error checking, are implemented to ensure the integrity of long-term datasets. Furthermore, comprehensive datasets are collected to support the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases by recognizing oasis–desert interactions and maintaining the balance between these systems.
